course.subject: PHYS
course.name: Electricity and Magnetism II
course.description: Electrodynamics: applications of Maxwell's equations, propagation in various media, radiation, relativistic electrodynamics, transmission lines and wave guides.
course.prerequisites: PHYS 3033 OR PHYS 3053

reviews.author: TM-AN
reviews.comment_content: Griffith Introduction To Electrodynamics 4th Edition Ch. 7.3 to 12 (second half of the book) + One lecture on advanced topic (this year the topic is optical precursor)
reviews.comment_teaching: Lecture content is basically the same as the textbook, so you may be more productive by reading the textbook yourself (except for the advanced lecture).
reviews.comment_grading:
HW 20%, Mid-term 35%, Final 45%.
Mean: 78.9  My score: 73.9
Grade: C+
Probably the mean is around B- (or perhaps B?) and the grading is by curve.

This is a required course for IRE track and honor option, and in this semester a total of 15 people enrolled in this course. And, FYI, in my year there are 13 PHYS-IRE students in total (from PHYS2080 student list). What does this mean? Although I do not know exactly how many IRE people enrolled this course this year, one can expect most (if not all) of them are either in IRE track or honor option (or enthusiastic strong mainland students). In this sense, it is really difficult to say if this course have a better grading than YZY's PHYS1314 (I did not give E for grading simply because it is formally not stated as a honor course).

For those who have to take this course in the future, this course may be one of the biggest academic challenges to your MCGA/CGA if you want to be a physics researcher in the future, so you should be prepared to spend extensive effort in it.
reviews.comment_workload: 8 HW in total, 3-5 questions from Griffith textbook per HW.

reviews.author: Alan123321
reviews.comment_content: The course syllabus is the second half of the Griffiths' book (Introduction to electrodynamics). Homework and some exam questions were taken from this book so I would recommend doing all exercises if you want to get good grades.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching is fair. He sometimes carried away from the main topic to discuss off-topic applications but went back quickly. The pace is a bit on the slower side, his English accent is OK and easy to understand.
reviews.comment_grading: This is the first C grade I got so far for physics courses. The professor clearly said that the grading was on curve fitting basis, but considering that usually good physics students in Honor option or IRE track would pick this course I would say getting a good grade would be more difficult than normal physics courses. Same logic with QM II but I feel that Prof. Leung did give grades to students much more generously.
reviews.comment_workload: One homework per week, with all questions directly taking from Griffiths' book. So finding source should not be a problem.

reviews.author: tesserakt
reviews.comment_content:
The content covers the latter half of Griffiths, including

1. electromagnetic energy and momentum
2. electromagnetic wave
3. potentials (gauge transform, Lorentz gauge and retarded potential)
4. radiation of dipole, accelerating point charge, etc.
5. electrodynamics and relativity

All of them (except 4 probably) are essential in the picture of classical electrodynamics.

Prof. Zhang also attempts to provide more details that the textbook lacks (e.g. the derivation of retarded potential using Green function) if he thinks this is useful.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Zhang is a well-intentioned teacher who likes to emphasize on the conceptual side of physics. How he often provides additional materials and alternative derivations for the results in the textbook are proofs of that.

Unfortunately, he speaks in a low voice and stammers a lot, which makes it straining to follow his teaching. Moreover, he is not so familiar with the use of software (perhaps a result of his old age), which has caused quite a bit of hiccups.
reviews.comment_grading:
Interestingly, absolutely nothing about the grading scheme of the course is released on canvas (perhaps because Prof. Zhang is unfamiliar with the system). No information about the final examination is released either.

Despite this, the overall grading seems to be quite good. I got an A+ with 94/100 in mid-term (the average is ~70 and the maximum is 100), while another friend I know got an A.

I refrain from giving an A due to incomplete information.
reviews.comment_workload:
We have around two to four questions from Griffiths to finish every week. The difficulty of the questions varies from week to week, and it can get quite tedious often due to the complicated mathematics.

There are also quite a bit of formulas and results in the textbook to get acquainted with before the mid-terms and finals. Even though necessary formulas are provided for the questions, you should be familiar with the concepts (and mathematics) involved in the textbook.

reviews.author: 左右手
reviews.title: EM II
reviews.comment_content:
主要教Griffiths 黑皮書後半部份，學電動力學。最難的部分相信係Radiation 同埋Relativity，算式較為複雜。考試無cheatsheet 或者formula sheet，所以必須將書上所有公式倒背如流，而且識得derive。由於教完成本書仲有一堂剩，所以就拎左黎教superconductor 幾個基本的properties。

-Applications of Maxwell's equations
-Transmission lines and wave guides
-Propagation in various media,
-Momentum
-Radiation,
-Relativistic electrodynamics
-(Superconductor)
reviews.comment_teaching: 教授英文非常流利，講解都算好清楚，可以帶你由物理的角度睇每一條公式，好有insight。呢個Course 無notes，上堂Prof. 會用白板derive 書上的公式，節奏快，至於抄唔抄就睇你自己，因為其實書上面都有，但Prof. 有時會用d 另外的方法derive。上堂用的係Guassian unit，而書上面的題目係S.I., 所以會有d 唔慣，但某程度上咁都有好處，如果你睇d 再深d 的書，好多都係用Gaussian 唔用S.I..
reviews.comment_grading:
成個Course 無功課，兩個quiz (全部係書題目，上堂有解過一次)，mid term 同final。考試難道中上，B Range 闊，A Range 極窄。全部close book，請務必背熟所有公式。我建議做曬書上面岩做的題目同埋close book derive 一次d equations。

Quiz: 30%
Mid term: 30%
Final: 40%
reviews.comment_workload: 無tutorial，無功課，但由於要差唔多背曬半本書，所以都chur chur地，無得爆發，要提早溫。

reviews.author: Qsdhbka
reviews.title: First course in electrodynamics
reviews.comment_content:
Basically following the second half of Griffiths’ textbook with some supplementary topics:
Starting with a brief review of Chapter 7, Maxwell Equations and boundary conditions, then proceed to Chapter 8, energy and momentum of EM fields including angular momentum.
Chapter 9 focuses on important applications of Maxwell Equations: EM waves propagating in linear materials(homogeneous and inhomogeneous) and conducting linear materials (obeying Ohm’s law), Lorentz’s model of dispersion, rectangular waveguides and coaxial transmission lines, and also a useful technique (impedance matching) in solving inhomogeneous medium.
Chapter 10, setting the foundation of the analysis of radiation, introduces the important concept of retarded potentials (not to mention the gauge transformation) and calculates the retarded potentials for point charges.
Chapter11, said to be the hardest one, deals with radiation, including dipole radiation, radiation of arbitrary source(multi-pole expansion of radiation) and point charge radiation. The professor also prepares two notes on antenna theory, modeling the radiation of a linear antenna and antenna array.
Chapter 12 is the relativistic theory of electrodynamics where many puzzles in the previous chapters become clear.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Foreman is a great teacher. He almost never skips any steps in derivations in both notes and lectures. His notes are super clear. Any seemingly complicated topics becomes easy to understand either mathematically or intuitively. He encourages students to ask any kinds of question in class — “there are no stupid questions” — and he always tries to answer as detailed as possible and has to make sure we all understand it.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading, I think, is fine for such a small class of 20 students.

There are two grading schemes:
20% homework, 35% midterm, 45% final
20%homework, 20% midterm, 60%final
(Both with 3% bonus for asking questions in class)
Taking the higher one as your final grade.

The questions in the exams, except the first question is from the text book, are all designed by our professor. They are all very good questions which test your analytical skills with some usual theoretical models, but not quite easy.

One interesting feature of the grades in both midterm and final is that the first sd above mean is almost high.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload of this course, to be honest, is not light. Because of the difficulty and complexity of the contents, the calculations in particular are very heavy. To finish one homework, you might need quite a few hours. In order to prepare for the exams, it would be safe if you go through some essential exercises on the textbook and work them out on your own (of course not to mention rederiving the formulas given in the notes). All in all, if you really want to learn this course well, you had better devote quite a lot of time to it.
